II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

2. 
Road  density  in  Sri  Lanka  is  higher  than  that  in  many  developing  countries;  however, 
road network standards and conditions are inadequate to meet the rapidly growing freight and 
passenger  traffic.  This  situation  limits  the  contribution  of  roads  to  national  development, 
economic  growth,  and  poverty  reduction.  To  cope  with  the  constraints,  the  existing  road 
infrastructure  must  be  improved  and  upgraded.  The  overall  contribution  of  road  infrastructure 
also requires institutional arrangements and capacity that support strategic management of the 
sector,  and  planning  and  management  of  investments.  Since  2002,  the  Asian  Development 
Bank  (ADB)  has  supported  the  establishment  and  implementation  of  a  policy  and  institutional 
framework to improve overall road sector performance. The proposed Project will be the second 
in  the  series  of  interventions,  and  will  support  the  second  stage  of  the  reform  program  and 
finance the upgrading of national highways (NHs). The proposed Project, which was envisaged 
in  the  country  strategy  and  program  2004–2008,1 is  designed  to  address  both  investment  and 
institutional aspects in the sector.2 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

3. 
Sri  Lanka  has  a  road  network  of  about  108,000  kilometers  (km),  comprising  about 
11,700  km  of  NHs,  15,500  km  of  provincial  roads,  64,700  km  of  local  authority  roads,  and 
16,300 km of roads owned or controlled by irrigation, wildlife and land development authorities. 
The road sector analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
4. 
The  Ministry  of  Highways  (MOH)  has  overall  responsibility  for  policies  and  programs 
concerning  the  NH  network.  RDA,3 a  statutory  institution  assigned  to  MOH,  is  responsible  for 
planning  and  managing  the  development  and  maintenance  of  NHs.  Although  RDA  has  the 
structure  of  a  commercial  organization—with  a  chairman,  a  general  manager,  and  a  board  of 
directors—in  practice  it  operates  as  a  government  department  under  MOH,  with  relatively 
limited  autonomy.  The  Ministry  of  Transport  (MOT)  has  responsibility  for  overall  policy  and 
regulation  in  land  transport,  covering  road  and  rail  transport.    Among  its  functions,  MOT  is 
responsible  for  vehicle,  driver,  and  operator  licensing;  on-road  regulatory  enforcement  in 
cooperation with the police; and passenger transport services and price regulation.  
 
5. 
Sri  Lanka’s  real  gross  domestic  product  over  10  years  period  grew  at  the  average  of 
4.5% per annum, and the rate of traffic growth was over 6% annually in the last 5 years. Road 
transport is a dominant mode, accounting for 98% of freight movement and 93% of passenger

Although road accidents have increased at a rate lower than the growth in vehicle fleet 
or  the  estimated  operated  vehicle-km,  the  number  of  death  has  increased  during  the  last  two

Bus  transport  services  are  the  leading  form  of  public  transport  in  Sri  Lanka,  providing 
approximately 80% of passenger transport; railways and private vehicle owners contribute 7% 
and 13%, respectively. The publicly owned cluster bus companies (CBCs) have a 22% share of 
the total bus transport market, implying a high reliance on the private sector for provision of the 
services. CBCs pose a substantial financial burden due to the high operating cost per km and 
poor targeting of subsidies for unprofitable school and rural bus routes. Currently, CBCs employ 
12 persons per operated bus, and own 4,200 buses. The total cost of operating CBCs including 
corporate cost, depreciation, and all fees payable to the Government amounted to SLRs21.91 
billion in 2004. The main reason for the significant cost can be a combination of excess staff and 
salary structures. In addition, the sector has suffered from lack of a sound policy and regulatory 
framework,  including  infrequent  fare  increases,  which  have  not  allowed  service  delivery  at 
financially viable levels and have led to lack of investment in the sector. The fare structure has 
also  caused  overcrowding  on  more  profitable  routes  and  underprovision  on  others,  and  low 
service quality and increasing safety issues.

Institutional and Organizational Aspects 

One  of  the  objectives  of  the  sector  reform  program  is  to  enhance  RDA's  efficiency  in 
27.

28. 
RDA  was  established  in  1981  through  the  RDA  Act  (No.  73).  In  line  with  the  Act, 
currently  there  are  five  appointed  members  and  five  other  members  representing  different 
ministries.  Of  the  appointed  members,  one  holds  a  full  time  appointment  and  serves  as 
chairman. In addition, there is a general manager (GM) who is in charge of the overall business 
of RDA, including administrative control of RDA’s employees.  
 
At present, RDA’s operations are being carried out through 15 divisions and 9 provincial 
29. 
offices,  each  headed  by  a  director  (Appendix  5).  This  arrangement  results  in  the  GM’s  very 
large span of control, which adversely affects the efficient function and coordination of RDA. It 
gives  the  GM  insufficient  time  to  establish  close  top  management  relationship  with  his 
immediate subordinates which is needed for effective control and direction of the organization. 
In addition, 10 project management units (PMUs), each headed by a project director in charge 
of externally funded and special projects and programs, report directly to the secretary of MOH. 
 
An alternative structure (the RDA reorganization plan) to ensure manageability of RDA’s 
30. 
works,  particularly  the  core  businesses  as  mandated  by  the  RDA  Act,  has  been  approved  by 
RDA’s  Board.  It  is  structured  along  four  functional  areas:  (i)  planning  and  programming,  (ii) 
asset  development,  (iii)  asset  management,  and  (iv)  finance  and  administration.  Each  will  be 
headed  by  an  additional  GM.  In  addition,  a  central  support  service  office  will  be  established,

(ESD)  with  responsibilities  for  environmental  impact  studies  and  clearance,  and  LAR.  The 
divisions will report directly to the GM. The proposed RDA organizational chart (Appendix 6) will 
enable  RDA  to  have  sound  public management  in  the  road  sector.  The  ultimate  structure,  job 
description  of  each  function,  staff  and  budget  implication,  and  implementation  time  frame  are 
being worked out by RDA’s task force.

89. 
The Project will improve the overall performance of the sector, contributing to transport 
efficiency,  and  widening  access  to  economic  opportunities.  The  project  beneficiaries  will  be 
people,  companies,  and  government  and  nongovernment  agencies in Sri  Lanka  that  use  road 
transport  services  directly  and  indirectly.  Communities  served  by  the  project  roads  will  benefit 
from improved, lower cost, and faster transport services, and thereby obtain improved access to 
economic opportunities and social services. Operators of both passenger and freight transport 
services will benefit from improved roads in terms of lower vehicle operating cost (VOC), time 
savings,  and  improved  road  safety,  and  thereby  increase  productivity.  Government  and 
nongovernment agencies served by the project roads will be able to improve its service delivery. 
 
Those  benefits  and  positive  impacts  will  occur,  assuming  that  complementary  external

implemented in full, leading to less-than-intended improvements in sector performance; (ii) post 
project road maintenance will be inadequate; and (iii) counterpart funding will be inadequate.

Bus  transport  services  are  the  leading  form  of  public  transport  in  Sri  Lanka,  providing 
9. 
approximately  80%  of  road  passenger  transport;  railways  contribute  7%;  and  private  vehicle 
owners account for the remaining 13%. The publicly-owned cluster bus companies (CBCs) have 
a 22% share of the total bus transport market, implying high reliance on the private sector for 
provision  of  bus  transport  services,  i.e.,  78%  private  sector  market  share.  The  CBCs  have  a 
substantial financial burden due to the high operating cost per km (SLRs45.63 per operated bus 
km  by  the  CBCs  compared  with  SLRs36.21  per  km  for  buses  operated  by  the  private  sector) 
and poor targeting of subsidies to CBCs for unprofitable school and rural bus routes. The CBCs 
currently  employ  12  persons  per  operated  bus.  They  own  8,400  buses,  of  which  only  4,200 
remain operational. The total cost of operating a public bus amounted to SLRs80.55 per km or a 
total  of  SLRs21.97  billion  in  2004.  The  main  reason  for  the  significant  operating  cost  of  the 
CBCs  can  be  a  combination  of  excess  staff  and  salary  structures.  In  addition,  the  passenger 
transport sector previously suffered from the lack of a sound policy and regulatory framework, 
including infrequent fare increases, which have not allowed service delivery at financially viable 
levels and led to lack of investment in the sector. The fare structure also led to overcrowding on 
more  profitable  routes  and  underprovision  on  others,  and  a  general  public  perception  of  low 
service quality in combination with increasing safety issues and accidents. 

10. 
The  Government  has  outlined  a  detailed  reform  program  to  address  these  substantial 
issues.  Recognizing  that  a  mere  change  from  public  to  private  ownership  will  not  solve  the 
underlying  issues  impeding  improved  sector  performance,  the  Cabinet  approved  a  strategic 
action  plan  in  April  2005.  The  main thrust  of  the  strategy  is to  depoliticize  transport  regulation 
and  introduce  commercial  principles  in  the  management  of  the  CBCs  by  reestablishing  the 
Central Transport Board, ensuring objective management appointment procedures, introducing 
efficiency and thus reduce the burden on public finances. One of the main tools applied is the 
introduction  of  franchising  schemes  formulated  on  the  principle  of  competition  for  the  market 
and  improved  methods  of  procuring  and  managing  the  services  of  private  buses.2 The  action 
plan also aims at reducing the number of persons per operated bus to 4.25 by reducing the total 
employees from more than 40,000 to 16,000 through a voluntary retirement scheme.

Annual  road  fatalities  have  been  increasing  over  the  last  5  years,  both  in  total  and  in 
relation to population. The number of fatalities increased from 2,023 in 1998 to 2,185 in 2002. 
The fatalities per 100,000 population slightly increased from 11.28 in 1998 to 11.5 in 2002. MOT 
published  a  strategic  plan  for  road  safety,  covering  (i)  involvement  and  coordination  of 
stakeholders,  (ii)  constructive  participation  of  media,  (iii)  development  of  leadership  and 
securing funding for the safety plan, and (iv) establishing a monitoring and evaluation process. 
This  overall  strategy  will  be  directed  to  four  target  areas:  (i)  road  infrastructure  safety 
improvements—removal of hazardous encroachments and obstructions, black spot remediation 
on the major arterials in Western Province, and development of safety-related standards within 
RDA;  (ii)  road  users—driver  licensing  and  testing  improvements,  public  awareness  programs, 
vehicle roadworthiness testing, random roadside vehicle checks, and nighttime visibility aids for 
pedestrians and cyclists; (iii) traffic law and enforcement—improved enforcement resources and 
techniques,  a  demerit  point  system,  implementing  existing  provisions  of  the  Motor  Traffic  Act, 
encouraging  seat  belt  wearing;  and  (iv)  road  safety  management—road  safety  committees, 
activate and staff the National Road Safety Secretariat, implement a pilot project on prehospital

SUMMARY OF DESIGN STANDARDS AND FEATURES 

Design Standards and Guidelines. The design criteria adopted are generally in accordance 
1. 
with  the  standards  in  use  by  the  Road  Development  Authority  (RDA),  and  include  the  Geometric 
Design  Standards  of  Roads  1998,  and  Guide  to  the  Structural  Design  of  Roads  under  Sri  Lankan 
Conditions 1999. RDA has generally based its geometric, pavement, and traffic design standards on 
Australian (AustRoads/NAASRA) practice and standards which, in turn, use standards derived from 
the  Federal  Highway  Administration’s  Highway  Capacity  Manual.  The  pavement  design  standards 
used  by  RDA  are  based  partly  on  Transport  Research  Laboratory’s  Overseas  Road  Note  31, 
including the design chart approach to specifying pavement layer design in relation to design of axle 
loads.  RDA  uses  United  Kingdom  design  standards  in  bridge  design.  Road  safety  audits  are  built 
into the engineering designs and followed through during the construction period in accordance with 
the Asian Development Bank’s Road Safety Toolkit. In densely populated areas, the roads and their 
associated  sidewalks  are  made  accessible  to  all  including  the  disabled  people  in  accordance  with 
the Department for International Development’s Overseas Road Note No. 21 Enhancing the Mobility 
of Disabled People: Guidelines for practitioners. 

2. 
Pavement  Treatment.  The  existing  pavement  is  generally old  penetration  macadam,  often 
over an earlier hand-laid stone base, with some later surface treatment applications, typically sand 
seals.  Existing  carriageway  width  is  typically  4.5  m  to  6.0  meters  (m)  with  up  to  1.0  m  of  earth 
shoulder.  There are some narrower sections, where steep mountainous and rocky terrain constrains 
the alignment, and some wider sections, typically at the approach to larger villages and towns. The 
existing pavement thickness varies and has been found to be generally thicker and more intact over 
the central part of the road and thinner and more broken at the edges. On some hill sections, poor 
side  drainage  has  led  to  scour  along  the  pavement  edge.  While  there  are  extensive  areas  of 
pavement that require reconstruction, there are also sections where the existing pavement can form 
a base to the improved road. 

3. 
The pavement design for reconstructed and widened sections is by way of RDA’s pavement 
structural  catalogue,  which  provides  layered  designs  for  combinations  of  subgrade  strength  and 
design axle load. A 10-year design period has been used which could be extended to 15–20 years 
with proper maintenance and axle load control. The pavement type will be asphalt concrete (AC) for 
higher  loads  or  double  bituminous  surface  treatment  (DBST)  for  lower  design  axle  loads.  For 
pavements constructed over existing surfaces, the TRL method for overlay design has been used, 
generally without any expectation of residual pavement life from the old pavement. Where existing 
pavement  is  to  be  overlaid  but  AC  is  not  warranted,  then  a  regulating  and  strengthening  layer  of 
bitumen-bound base and DBST is proposed. 

Cross  Section.  All  roads  are  to  be  designed  as  two-lane.  In  one  case,  for  the  termination

flows, where width is reduced to a minimum of 3.0 m.  Shoulder widths vary from 3.0 m in flat terrain 
to a minimum of 1.0 m in mountainous terrain. Where there is significant cycle traffic and the road

Productivity of Land Purchase

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Sri Lanka: 
In  Sri  Lanka,  lack  of  capacity  and  poor  condition  of  roads  are  the  main  constraints  preventing  poor  people  from 
gaining  access  to  economic  opportunities  and  good  quality  services.  An  efficient  road  network  linking  villages, 
towns,  and  cities  will  provide  stronger  linkages  between  remote  and  poor  regions  and  more  developed  markets. 
Road  development  encourages  other  development  initiatives,  which  together  considerably  stimulate  economic 
growth. It is expected to significantly improve the socioeconomic situation and enhance poverty reduction.  

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                Poverty Classification:  General intervention 
 
The Project covers widening and improvement of approximately 270 kilometers (km) of the road network comprising 
nine  road  sections  traversing  both  rural  and  urban  districts  in  seven  provinces,  namely,  Central,  North  Central, 
Southern, Uva, Western, Sabaragamuwa, and Northwestern.  Central Province, where a large number of tea estates 
and small tea producers are located, has the largest number of towns and villages covered under the Project. The 
poverty  levels  in  these  districts  vary  considerably.  Colombo  in  Western  Province  has  the  lowest  at  5%  and 
Monaragala  and  Badulla  in  Uva  Province  the  highest  at  32%.  The  poverty  levels  in  Kegalle  district  of 
Sabaragamuwa  is  nearly  30%  with  Hambantota  district  of  Southern  Province  at  27%.  Similarly,  poverty  levels  are 
high in Matara district of Southern province and Matale district of Central Province at 24%. The estimated monthly 
income of those living below the poverty level (BPL) is SLRs1,423 (less than $15) in each district. The project areas 
are  predominantly  rural  and  pass  through  approximately  300  villages  and  97  towns  including  3  urban  centers. 
Limited access of the rural and urban poor to socioeconomic services is one of the major causes of poverty in the 
project area. In terms of health indicators, Nuwara Eliya district of Central Province, which has a high proportion of 
workers  living  on  tea  plantations,  has  high  rates  of  maternal  deaths  (0.7  per  1,000  live  births)  and  infant  mortality 
rates  (20.7),  followed  by  Anuradhapura  (North  Central)  at  22.5  and  Badulla  district  (Uva)  at  20.9,  with  its  rural 
population depending on subsistence agriculture. In terms of educational facilities, the project districts had fair share 
of primary schools, however, secondary schools were understaffed due to transport limitations or difficult to access.  
 
Social assessment carried out in the sample roads passing through Central and Uva provinces revealed that nearly 
49% of the sample households lived BPL1 while for Western Province, the figure was 29%. With regard to education 
levels,  about  62%  of  the  sample  households  in  Central,  Uva,  and  Western  provinces  had  attended  only  primary 
schools. In the sample households in Central Province and Uva, male household heads were better educated than 
female  household  heads.  No  difference  in  educational  attainment  of  male  and  female  household  heads  was 
observed in Western Province. Nearly 75% of sample households in Central and Uva and 59% in Western provinces 
were salaried or earned daily wages. Among these households, heads of households were 69–80% male and only 
one third were female. The survey also identified 20–27% households where women were the main income earner. 
Men were predominantly engaged in agriculture, trade, government service, and private jobs. Women were mostly 
into agriculture and trade and worked in the garment industries. It was observed that most people living BPL were 
engaged in agriculture, where wage laborers were in small trade or businesses. 
 
The poverty impact ratio was 0.39, which was estimated by determining how much of the benefits to each class of 
user  in  the  distribution  analysis  are  passed  on  to  the  poor.  Community  participation  through  key  respondent 
interviews and focus group discussions in the project areas highlighted several major perceived project benefits: 
(i)  Reduction  of  travel  time:  Better  roads  will  improve  the  economic  productivity  of  people  in  public  and  private 
enterprises, including teachers, medical staff, and government employees.  
(ii) Increased access to quality health service:  Better roads will facilitate faster and convenient travel by women, 
especially pregnant mothers, and children and the elderly to access quality health services.  Communities may also 
benefit from increased availability of medical and educational staff in more remote villages due to ease of travel. 
(iii)  Improved  access  to  educational  facilities:    A  number  of  villages  are  without  local  schools;  hence  children 
attending school in nearby villages or in the closest town center rely mostly on public bus for transport. The Project 
will increase the regularity of the bus trips to the villages and help children reach school on time.
